This Spring Statement can start that journey and reset our priorities.

As Russia shows, we don’t get to choose when we need to be ready, but if we’ve got the connections, the troops and the warning, we can make the best choices for Britain. 13/13

We may be an island nation but we’re a global hub. We rely on food and energy markets that are shaped by others and we buy things made from Shanghai to Seattle.

We need to think again about resilience and investing our defences. 12/13

Commitment to building LNG carriers now, and the rapid increase in nuclear plants so we’re no longer held hostage by prices in the future.

Support to agriculture and manufacturing around the world and the trade relationships for them to profit from their output. 11/13

So tomorrow, I’d like to see:

Our @FCDOGovUK budget rise and the leadership and management failures fixed.

Increased defence spending including cyber and technology development alongside our universities.

Build up of our stocks and the capability to resupply ourselves. 10/13
So we need to invest in our security - economic and military. That means transforming our overseas arms and investing in resilience at home. 9/13

The war in Ukraine shows why understanding and influence matters.

War has returned to Europe and only @NATO is containing the violence - at huge cost to Ukraine. 8/13

Today, @BritishArmy is smaller than anytime since Napoleon threatened Europe. @RoyalNavy has too few ships to sustain global operations and, along with @RoyalAirForce has too few F-35s for a single carrier.

We’ve banked the peace dividend from the end of the Cold War. 7/13

We need to know so we can influence the outcomes in the interest of our people. Aid, trade and intelligence are key to shaping the future. That’s what diplomats do.

Our forces give us options but, as @Tobias_Ellwood has warned, they’re now too small. 6/13

That will have huge implications for us.

What goods will we buy if transport costs are higher?

What will nations try to do to distract from problems at home?

How will economies adapt - or not - to the rising pressures?

How many will try to move to find work or hope? 5/13

In the Middle East and Africa we will see hunger and unrest. @WFPChief has already warned what that means for migration.

In China and other energy hungry states, oil over $100 a barrel will slow growth and hurt the poorest. 4/13

That’s why we need to see investment tomorrow in two areas:

1. @FCDOGovUK
2. @DefenceHQ 

Our energy dependence and food costs are only the start. 3/13

What happens abroad shapes our lives at home.

Wheat from Ukraine feeding millions today and energy from Russia heats homes across Europe this winter are both in trouble.

Rising global labour costs are pushing up the prices of goods like TVs.

We’re all feeling it. 2/13

Tomorrow’s Spring Statement will focus on the rising bills we’re all seeing.

Food, fuel, even goods are going up. The Chancellor will be looking for ways to help families across Britain.

He’ll need to look beyond our borders to make a long term difference. 1/13

This makes the pivot to Asia, for both Britain and the US, a reality. And makes the future of Australia more secure.
Tonight our allies - and our citizens - are safer. That’s what foreign policy should deliver.

The nuclear boats are at the vanguard of a stronger future. 13/

Tonight, Beijing will have realised the pressure on Australia has triggered a response. This is a powerful answer to those who thought the US was pulling back and the propaganda claiming Washington wasn’t a reliable ally. 12/

And #AUKUS can help them too. Britain’s key role has been as a network enabler, helping many work together. Now we can do that with advanced technology and future capabilities. We can work to bring others with us. 11/

We don’t have the strategic depth of our two partners. We need allies to extend our military frontier as far as we can - to the easternmost borders of Lithuania and Latvia, and the Mediterranean Sea. Europe still matters to us. We can’t opt out of geography. 10/
And others will be worried that this new alliance could see us diminish our commitment to @NATO’s European tasks in favour of new horizons. We need to reassure them we’re not going anywhere. 9/

While Australia, UK and US together ensure global coverage, others are vital to our future stability at home in Europe. The French, who will be smarting at this decision to abandon their diesel-electric boat, will be worried they’re cut out of all future contracts. 8/

The next steps are obvious - a permanent port for our own boats operating in the region; a joint fleet to ensure complete cooperation; the gradual inclusion of regional partners. But we must also remember others. 7/

Australia should have bought nuclear powered boats in 2016 but the anti-nuclear lobby were stronger and the threats less stark. Now none of us have the luxury of opting for trading capability for politics. The price is too high. 6/
And nor did the US or UK. We know that we need a regional power and to partner with and the nation that most closely shares our interests, and can be relied on completely, is Oz. 5/

The reason for all this is clear - China. After years of bullying and trade hostility, and watching regional neighbours like the Philippines see encroachment into their waters Australia didn’t have a choice. 4/

From artificial intelligence to advanced technology the US, UK and Australia will now be able to cost save by increasing platform sharing and innovation costs. Particularly for the smaller two, that’s game-changing. 3/
Bringing together the military industrial complex of these three allies together is a step change in the relationship. We’ve always been interoperable, but this aims at much more. 2/
The #AUKUS agreement is about much more than boats. Nuclear powered submarines are essential to supporting allies like Japan and defend Australia but the real gain is long term. 1/

We can turn this around. We need to.
Investing in ourselves, our allies and partners has never been easier or more important. This is a choice. So far we’re choosing to lose. 19/

That’s why I’m angry. It’s wasteful and unnecessary. And why it’s personal? Because I’ve seen what it costs and what sacrifices are being thrown away. And I know who’s going to pay for it - we will. Britain is weakened when the US and NATO is weakened. 18/

That’s bad for us - it makes us look untrustworthy.
It’s bad for our allies - it leaves them looking exposed.
It’s bad for our future - it encourages rivals to challenge us.
And it didn’t need to happen. We have chosen to leave. We haven’t been forced out. 17/

Many countries are too small and weak. A brief deployment we make them look cheap. They can’t afford the reputational cost of a one night stand, they need a marriage proposal. After 20 years, billions of dollars and thousands of lives, Afghanistan now looks like a fling. 16/
We don’t need to lose this struggle. We’re ahead by miles and we have friends who are willing us on, but they’re also watching us at home and abroad and wonder if we really have the commitment. 15/

We could rebuild partnerships and alliances. Invest in supporting friends and building coalitions. It costs money, it takes time, but the reward is a world of free people to trade with, who are allowed to share our values, not live in fear. 14/

So you want to know why I’m angry? Because we don’t need to do this. Because it is about our freedom tomorrow not just Afghanistan today. Because the only defeat is of our own making. We could decide to act differently. 13/

Loans from Chinese state banks build infrastructure across the world as we’re cutting our aid rather than turning it into investment. Russian military support and sales are going to countries we snub pushing them into the arms of those who oppose what we value. 12/

We know that when free people choose, they choose freedom. They come to UK, US, not China or Russia. But we’re closing doors. Nigerians get commercial visas to China easily, to Britain, it’s hard. 11/

The G7+ who met in Cornwall this summer make up c70% of world trade. China, less than 20%. Russia isn’t even relevant.

We have the financial, commercial, intellectual, military, developmental and cultural ability to defend our interests. 10/

And we know what that means. Less easy trade. Obstacles to cooperation. Confrontation over disputes.

But despite their size, neither is able to break our system unless we walk away. 9/

This isn’t just about Afghanistan. It’s about us all. We are engaged in a challenge over the way the world works.

We’re seeing autocratic powers like China and Russia challenge the rules and break the agreements we’ve made to keep us all safe. 8/
Training a man to fight with his eyes open and then blindfolding him before his title bout is going to have only one result. 7/

That means battle winning technology we had taught the Afghans to rely on is useless. Billions of dollars of assets, wasted. Instead of a sustainable peace, incrementally building, we’re seeing a rout. Of course we are. 6/

The decision to withdraw is like a rug pulled from under the feet of our partners. No air support, none of the maintenance crews able to service their equipment - that was done by US contractors, now gone. 5/
We got to the point where the insurgent forces were outmatched and a standoff saw civic institutions grow. No, it wasn’t perfect, but it was growing and time was deepening the roots of society. 4/

But through failure and hardship we changed the odds. It stopped being US or NATO fighting but the Afghan Police and Army. We built trust and ensured they had the support they needed to sustain operations. 3/

Many of us gave all we could. The operation broke us. Worse, it tore families apart, left children orphans and parents to cry alone. The father carrying his bloodied daughter desperately looking for the help that was now useless haunts me every time I carry my own child. 2/
